Award.AwardTitle: The Impact of Downward Wave Coupling on the Tropospheric Circulation
Award.AbstractNarration: The PI will investigate the dynamical nature of the impact of downward wave coupling (DWC) on the tropospheric circulation and climate in reanalysis data and its representation in a state-of-the-art seasonal forecast and climate model. The goal is to assess the potential impact for seasonal forecasts and climate prediction in the troposphere. The research will focus on the Northern Hemisphere where the stratospheric variability allows for a clear separation of months with DWC and downward zonal mean coupling. The analysis will shed insights into the dynamical cause and evolution of individual wave reflection events and composite events to understand (i) the direct impacts of planetary wave reflection from the stratosphere on the phase and amplitude structure of the tropospheric wave pattern and (ii) the subsequent impacts of DWC on the tropospheric circulation both in the mid troposphere and the surface and how they compare to the impacts of downward zonal mean coupling. Increased understanding of the dynamical processes by which the stratosphere can influence the troposphere has the potential to lead to improved seasonal forecasting and climate prediction, thus leading to significant societal impacts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The stratosphere, the atmospheric layer between heights of about 10 to 50 km, has an important influence on surface winds and temperature during wintertime. An important component of the stratospheric flow is planetary-scale waves, driven by land-ocean contrasts and flow over topography, that extent upward from the troposphere. This project focused on the impact of stratospheric planetary wave variability on wintertime surface climate. The major outcomes of this project include i) a new definition of extreme stratospheric wave events and their impact on surface winds and temperature, which includes north-south shifts of the Atlantic storm track, ii) establishing a connection between extreme stratospheric wave events and abrupt reversal of stratospheric wind and mass circulation, ii) linking biases in the simulated position of the Atlantic storm track in state-of-the-art climate models to biases in stratospheric wave variability, suggesting the representation of stratospheric wave variability is important for simulating surface climate, and iv) an understanding of the dynamics of extreme stratospheric events using idealized numerical simulations.

The broader impacts of this project include the training of a graduate student in atmospheric and climate science. The graduate student presented the research results at national conferences. The outcomes of the project were published in international journals.
